Award.AwardTitle: Joint estimates of permeability using complex resistivity and proton nuclear magnetic resonance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modeling the flow of groundwater is fundamental for understanding the quantity of water available for human use, and the movement of chemicals, such as carbon, underground, into streams, and into the atmosphere. Accurate groundwater models require an understanding of the properties of soils and rocks that affect the flow of water (i.e. the permeability). Permeability is traditionally measured directly by inducing groundwater flow using pumping, slug, or packer tests; however, these methods can be limited by small measurement volumes and require the existence of wells. Indirect estimates of permeability based on geophysical techniques benefit from relatively short measurement times, do not require fluid extraction, and are non-invasive when made from the surface (or minimally invasive when made in a borehole). However, estimates of permeability based on a single geophysical method often require calibration for rock type, and cannot be used to determine all of the physical properties required to accurately determine permeability. This research focuses on developing an innovative method for estimating permeability based on the synergistic coupling of two complementary geophysical methods - complex resistivity (CR) and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) - aimed at providing a robust and minimally-invasive determination of permeability at the watershed scale.

The proposed research will use a combination of mechanistic model development, laboratory measurements, and field measurements to develop a permeability model based on CR and NMR parameters. The model and measurements will be tested at the Christina River Basin, an NSF funded Critical Zone Observatory (CRB-CZO), in which the accuracy of groundwater models has been limited by complex spatial variation in subsurface permeability. This research represents a critical step towards the development of joint NMR/CR measurements to obtain spatially dense information about permeability that will improve the quantitative characterization of groundwater flow.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary:

Modeling the flow of groundwater is fundamental for understanding the quantity of water available for human use, the flow and transport of contaminants, and the cycling of elements, such as carbon, underground, into streams, and into the atmosphere. Accurate groundwater models require an understanding of the properties of soils and rocks that affect the flow of water (i.e. the permeability). Permeability is traditionally measured directly by inducing groundwater flow using pumping, slug, or packer tests; however, these methods can be limited by small measurement volumes and require the existence of boreholes. Indirect estimates of permeability based on geophysical techniques benefit from relatively short measurement times, do not require fluid extraction, and are non-invasive when made from the surface (or minimally invasive when made in a borehole). Although there is a large body of research that focuses on estimating permeability from geophysical measurements, it is well known that estimates of permeability based on a single geophysical method often require calibration for rock type, and cannot be used to uniquely determine all of the physical properties required to accurately determine permeability. This research focused on developing methods for estimating permeability based on the synergistic coupling of two complementary geophysical methods - complex resistivity (CR) and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) - aimed at providing a robust and minimally-invasive determination of permeability at the borehole or plot scale.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Laboratory measurements on water saturated sandstone cores, collected as part of this research, showed that permeability estimates can be improved by combining CR and NMR parameters when compared to estimates made using either CR or NMR parameters alone. Additional laboratory measurements collected on water-saturated mixtures of sand and clay showed that the distribution of clay (either homogeneously distributed, or present in clusters of clay) within a sample strongly affects the NMR and CR measurements. Furthermore, unlike the internal surface area of the samples, CR and NMR parameters vary with permeability regardless of the way in which clay is distributed. This suggests that the geophysical measurements are more sensitive to the hydraulically interconnected pore geometry than the internal surface area, which is critical for estimating the permeability in field applications. Finally, surface NMR, electrical resistivity tomography, and borehole NMR measurements, collected in the New Jersey Pinelands over the Kirkwood-Cohasaney Aquifer were used to improve the hydrostratigraphical model of this region. Overall, we conclude that CR and NMR parameters are sensitive to important length-scales governing permeability and that these parameters can be combined to improve estimates of permeability. Furthermore, we conclude that these field geophysical measurements can provide valuable information for characterizing the hydrostratigraphy of sedimentary aquifers.  

 

Broader Impacts

This project provided opportunities for under-represented minorities to participate in active research, supported three graduate students, and promoted international research collaborations. To give the undergraduate students a meaningful research experience, they conducted independent research projects during the summer months (under the supervision of PI Keating, coPI Slater and a graduate student). In addition, the undergraduate students participated in the Hydrogeophysics workshop, a three-day workshop held at the Shale Hills Critical Zone Observatory and hosted by graduate students from Rutgers University, Newark. To promote international research collaborations, coPI Slater, a graduate student, and an undergraduate student visited Lancaster University in Lancaster, UK to collaborate with Professor Binley on laboratory CR measurements and data interpretation. In addition, with support from this project, one Master’s student and one PhD student, both successfully defended their dissertations.
